This is the castle tower of Takamatsu Castle in Takamatsu City, Kagawa Prefecture.
The castle was built by Chikamasa Ikoma, but later Yorishige Matsudaira, the lord of Takamatsu, completed the largest castle tower in Shikoku with three layers and five stories in 1670.
The castle tower was dismantled in 1884 due to deterioration, and the stone walls of the castle tower were at risk of collapsing due to weathering and earthquakes, so starting in 2007, the castle tower was excavated and surveyed for five years. Major renovations are underway, including dismantling the building, reinforcing the ground, and reassembling the stone walls as before.
The castle tower's stone wall, which is approximately 13 meters tall, is quite tall, but on top of that is a nearly 30 meter castle tower that juts out from the stone wall, and it must have been quite imposing.
I visited on a Sunday afternoon at the end of June, and there weren't that many tourists, so I was able to take my time and look around the castle tower, which was reserved for private use.
The castle tower has an observation deck where you can see the moat filled with seawater and the sheathed bridge.
The only way to access the castle tower is through the Saya Bridge, so it is closest from the west gate.

Visit period: June 2024

It is said to be the largest castle tower in Shikoku, with a three-story, five-story Nanban-style castle tower. A clear photo of the castle tower was discovered in the library of Cambridge University in the UK, so I would like to see it restored.

You can see a panoramic view of the city.
I am deeply moved to think that I would have seen a view like this back then.

I went on a humid day in May 2024.  You can spend 1-2 hours strolling around the walking paths taking in the scenery.  The lakes and flora are curated to look beautiful.  There are tons of koi fish as well.  Be sure to find the most beautiful spot in the Southern part of the garden on the hill!

There were also a few tea shops and stores inside if you want to feed the huge koi and have some snack yourselves. If you're going to Kagawa and have the time, this should be the top of your list.

It is located on the 4th floor of the same building as the library. There are exhibits about Takamatsu City from primitive times to postwar times. You can see valuable materials such as gold earrings from the Kofun period and a model of a feudal lord's barge from the Edo period. It's a shame that there aren't many medieval (Kamakura/Muromachi) exhibits, but it's worth more than the 300 yen admission fee. This is more recommended than the Prefectural Museum.

A museum located on the 4th floor of Sun Crystal Takamatsu. In the permanent exhibition room, you can look at Takamatsu's history through 12 themes through the ages. ① Establishment of the Takamatsu Plain, ② Development of rice cultivation and Takamatsu, ③ Ishikiyoyama Tumulus Group, ④ Buddhist culture and Takamatsu, ⑤ Genpei War and Yashima, ⑥ Samurai activities and Takamatsu, ⑦ Development of the castle town of Takamatsu, ⑧ Sanuki Sanpaku and Transportation, ⑨Culture of the townspeople and Takamatsu, ⑩Development of the modern city of Takamatsu, ⑪Takamatsu air raid, ⑫Takamatsu travelogue.
In addition, special exhibitions are also held. I went to see the ``Takamatsu Chronicle,'' which looks back on the history of Takamatsu since the end of the Edo period through photographs, and was surprised to find that there were many things that even Jimoti didn't know.
Although this is not the only issue, the modern and contemporary exhibits are a little weak.
I quickly stopped by by renting a bicycle. The special exhibition on Ryunosuke Akutagawa was interesting. Hiroshi Kikuchi connection.

reviews.text: The remaining structure, along with the Tsukimi Yagura, has been designated as an important cultural property of the country.
The historical site of Takamatsu Castle is cheap and only costs 200 yen to visit. You can see the ticket gate after walking three minutes from Takamatsu Chikko Tram Station.

This turret currently exists at Takamatsu Castle in Takamatsu City, Kagawa Prefecture. It is said to have been built around 1676 and is designated as an important cultural property.
I visited on a Sunday afternoon at the end of June, and the interior was open to the public for a limited time, so I was able to take a look.
The scenery where this turret, Mizute-gomon Gate, and Watari-yagura are lined up gives it the most castle-like atmosphere, and makes it easy to understand the functions of Mizuki.
It is a splendid building with three floors and three floors, as it was built to monitor the Seto Inland Sea. It is said to be the turret used to watch the feudal lord return by boat, so it is called ``Kurimi yagura'' → ``Tsukimi yagura''.
The stairs leading up to the third floor are at a very steep angle, so you need to be careful going up and down.
A cool breeze flows through the windows on the third floor, and you can see the ships coming in and out of Takamatsu Port. Damaged shachi tiles are also on display inside the room.

Visit period: June 2024

You can see the sea from the turret.
It is said that swimming was popular at that time.

It was from this turret that the feudal lord returned from Edo by boat.

reviews.text: An amazing word. It's hard to believe that this stone wall was built in the 7th century. And the view is outstanding. This is a must-visit spot when you come to Takamatsu or Yashima.

Yashima Castle, which I learned about for the first time in Buratamori
Explore while climbing Yashima from Kotoden-gatamoto Station
The stairs are steep and narrow, so climb slowly.

History is interesting!

Beer will be waiting for you when you reach the top 😅

Visited on July 30, 2022.
It is a mountain castle built by Prince Naka no Oe along the coast of the Seto Inland Sea from Tsushima and Kyushu in preparation for the invasion of Tang and Silla, and it is recorded in the Nihon Shoki that it was built in 667. It is an ancient mountain castle that made maximum use of the cliffs, and about 90% of the castle walls are natural cliffs.
The Yashima Castle ruins gate remains maintenance project that Takamatsu City has been working on since 2007 has been completed, and it has been open to the public since March 19, 2016.
The impressive stonework and the view of Takamatsu city are worth seeing. The view from the west ridge observation deck, which was also constructed at the same time, is also recommended.
From Udon Prefectural Travel Net
There is an explanation, so please take a look there for more details. There is also a QR code, so I tried calling it, but a message popped up saying that the page could not be found.

About a 10 minute walk southeast from Yashima Temple. You can see the stone wall left on the slope.
Since it was called a castle, I thought it was a relic from the Sengoku period, but it was actually built much earlier, in the 7th century, by Emperor Tenji to protect the country of Wa. I'm surprised that this was discovered only recently.

Nowadays, a promenade has been constructed, and you can see the castle gates up close.
From here, you can get a good view of the cityscape in the Takamatsu area below.
Of course, when the castle was built, the view from the castle would have been completely different than it is today.
What were the soldiers guarding the castle thinking as they looked out to the sea? When I think about this, I can't help but feel the romance of history.

I have been to Yashima from time to time, but I first came to Yashima Castle after seeing the Buratamori.
The recreated stone wall is worth seeing. You can learn about the history of Takamatsu and Yashima.
During the Edo period, Yashima was an island, with the sea extending as far as Rindo Station.

Yashima is good.
There is also an aquarium even though it is on top of a mountain. (Free until 2 years old)
It is also home to Yashima Temple, one of the 88 sacred sites in Shikoku.
A cafe is also available. LOL
Please feel free to explore it at least once.
It's refreshing to have a panoramic view of Takamatsu city.

reviews.text:
I went there for the first time because my child was on summer vacation and I was concerned about his lack of exercise.
It's spacious. Since it was summer vacation, there were a lot of customers, but it was spacious and had a lot of play equipment, so I didn't have to wait my turn to play.
There are separate spaces for small children and large children, so there were no scenes that I felt were too dangerous. There was also a nursing area in the corner.
I thought the kids would be drenched in sweat after playing so much, but the air conditioning was working properly and they were comfortable.
After playing for a while, I realized that there is a basketball ring in the back, badminton, table tennis, mini soccer, and a corner where you can play bouldering, so I think people of all ages can enjoy it.
In Takamatsu City, there are a fair number of facilities where preschoolers can play, but there are almost no places where elementary school students and older can play physically, so I think this place will be very helpful.
The fee is 1000 yen even if you stay all day, so if you have no other plans, you can play to your heart's content! I would like to use it when I want to. I will go again! This is a facility that I hope will continue for a long time.

Since you only have free time, I think it would be easier to use if there were pricing options such as a 3-hour package.
The facility had a lot of play equipment and game machines that I enjoyed.
It may have been because I was there on a Saturday and Sunday, but the staff did not clean regularly or warn children who were using the equipment in a dangerous manner, so it is at your own risk when using it. It's better to keep an eye on it.

There is no problem with the facility itself, and I think the price is high, but I think the price is reasonable.

However, I often see children not following the order of the play equipment and hogging it all to themselves.
Parents just say, ``Please follow your turn,'' and leave the children alone.
Even on weekdays when I'm free, there are kids like that who try to steal the toy car that my child tried to climb on, and the parents don't say anything.
If you can't properly teach your child, please don't use it.

I would also like to see facility staff work to resolve these issues.

I was able to play basketball, soccer, and table tennis. Magic year is a separate fee of 300 yen. There is also a corner for preschoolers, so it is safe.

The inside was very spacious and the children had fun playing at first, but even though there was a sign saying only preschoolers were allowed inside the play equipment, parents were stuck inside with their toddlers.
There were times when children in elementary school and above were using the play equipment only for preschoolers, and it was during spring break, but groups of 4 or 5 children were left feeling like they were the only ones who could use it even though there were other children around them. (Elementary school student), my own child complained about various things (almost always felt like it was the other party's fault).The parent of the child was not nearby, and other friends also had trouble with the child in the child's group. It's nice that they don't apologize and the fee is free to come and go, but it's expensive considering there are a lot of people with bad manners, and there are a lot of kids who run around and don't look, so I won't go there again 🙅‍♀️

According to reviews, it seemed like a pretty steep mountain, so I climbed it with caution. I parked my car under the antenna on the west side, but I don't know if it's okay or not. The mountain path is well maintained and easy to climb. There is a temple halfway up the mountain, and the path splits to the left and right, so you can proceed in a clockwise direction.

On the way, I saw a place where Fudo Myoo was carved into the cliff, and as I went further, I came across the rumored cliff. I see, I hesitate for a moment, but it looks old, but there is a rope and a place to hang your feet, so it looks like you can climb it. I get scared when I look at the scenery behind me, so I look only at what's in front of me and climb slowly. The scary part is probably about 20 to 30 meters.

I was wondering if I should take this route on my way back, but there is another route. There is one road that will take you to the neighboring Mt. Mantosan, and another road on the west side. There is a rocky area that is a bit rugged, but go down carefully. It became like a normal mountain road and came out to the left of the temple. If you are not confident about climbing the cliff, I think it is easier to climb from this direction.

I climbed down the cliff again, but the second time I did so, I had plenty of time to climb while enjoying the view. The views are spectacular in many places. From the top of the mountain, you can traverse to the next mountain. However, along the way, I was surrounded by bush mosquitoes and mematoi, so I couldn't check the route on my cell phone, and before I knew it, I was descending the mountain. I didn't feel like going to the insect mountain again, so I ended today.

This climb was quite interesting. Let's come back when the season is nice to see the historic temples and climb the cliffs.

This Mt. Garan (216m above sea level) is located in Mimaya-cho, Takamatsu City, Kagawa Prefecture. This is a mini-Mt. Fuji that is located on the north side of Prefectural Route 12 Miki Kokubunji Line and represents Sanuki, which has long been known as Sanuki's Three Dango Brothers!? It is a scenery that can be seen well even from a distance!? Today, the page In order to climb the mountain, we parked on the prefectural roadside on the south side of Mt. Garan (about 60m above sea level) and set off from the nearby trailhead! First, we headed to Yakushido (about 130m above sea level) in the middle of the mountain. I then proceeded along the mountain trail on the south side of Yakushido, but when I came across a rocky area, I hesitated. There was a steep cliff and we had to go up it!? Once we got to this point, we couldn't back up, so we had no choice but to go up!? This continues until we reach the top (altitude 216m). What is this! It was a mountain with a difficult course, which is rare among the mountains in Kagawa Prefecture! It seems that it was originally a training path for Shugendo people!?

The entrance was easily found along the prefectural road, but the trail that followed was difficult and steep. Although the height is not that great, there are some rocky areas that are quite sloped. You can't see much of a view from the top.

Mt. Garan Altitude: 216m
“Doyama – Rokumeyama (Mimaya Fuji) – Mt. Garan – Mt. Mantoyama (Mt. Sahako/Hazakōyama) Traverse”

From the Bamboo Forest trailhead, go down Mt. Doyama and Mt. Rokumoku to the ``high-speed trailhead''. Cross the expressway viaduct and walk along Prefectural Route 12 toward the mountain pass to the west and arrive at the Mt. Garan trailhead, which is on the opposite side of the road from your goal of ``Touge no Jizo.'' Now, let's start climbing Mt. Garan from here.

Unlike Mt. Doyama and Mt. Rokumoku, there are almost no guide signs on Mt. Garan. After climbing up the road for a while, we came to a wide mountain road. If you follow that path, you will see a temple. This is the inner temple of ``Ishizuchi Sanuki Betsuin Garanzan Mantoji Temple'', which is said to have been opened by Gyoki. From here, in front of me was a rock wall that looked almost perpendicular, and I couldn't find a starting point to climb up, but I turned back a little the way I had come and found a staircase on the right, so I climbed up from there. Ta.
This route climbs up a rocky area from the middle, and there are old hollows in the rocky area where you can place your hands and feet. I also saw old ropes that looked like they were going to break at any moment, but I didn't trust them so I didn't use them.However, it was quite a steep slope so I climbed carefully, calmly and calmly, step by step. On the way, I saw a sign that said, ``This is a Shugendo dojo, so the use of harkens, carabiners, etc. is prohibited,'' so I guess there's nothing I can do about it. (However, I climbed the mountain thinking that if this was the only route available, most people would be hesitant to climb this mountain, but when I looked it up on the internet after returning home, it seems that there is a detour route that goes directly in front of the temple.) So don't worry)

At the top of the mountain, there are only the Eight Great Ryuo Tenjin Shrine and the 4th grade triangulation point, but the summit is narrow and the view is limited. I didn't stay too long and headed down towards the next Mt. Manto (Mt. Sahako).

reviews.text: Decent gym but full of old people, wouldn't recommend for teenagers (particularly foreigners) unless you wanna get the stares 🤷‍♂️

I have been using this facility for over 10 years. It was very good in the beginning, but the quality has deteriorated over the years. Taking advantage of the fact that there are no other large sports facilities, they do not listen to the requests and complaints of members.
After the coronavirus pandemic, the air conditioner temperature setting in summer is ``27℃''
I can't imagine it being an environment for exercise!
No matter how many times I complain about how hot I feel like I'm going to collapse, it won't lower the temperature.
I heard that the instructions came from headquarters, but I can't help but think that there is something fundamentally wrong with this. I see many people who are feeling unwell due to heat stroke.
I wonder if this will be the case until someone is rushed to the hospital...

This was my first time using the facility, but the atmosphere inside the facility was nice, and I was able to ask questions about things I didn't understand about using the machines.
The staff's response is also very good.
There's also a pool, and it's a good facility for developing a variety of exercise habits.

I haven't been getting enough exercise lately, so I decided to rejoin the gym I used to join.
When I went up to the second floor to do some muscle training, it was like a sauna.
It was so hot that I asked the staff to lower the temperature, but they didn't respond.
I happened to know someone there, so when I talked to him, he seemed resigned and said, ``It's always like this, everyone says it's hot, but even when I talked to the staff, they couldn't talk about it.'' But I think so. Since you're paying money to come and exercise, it's the gym's responsibility to create an environment suitable for exercise!
The lobby and locker room are both hot.
That's a terrible story.
I go 6 times a week. I swim in the pool and work out. I have met some familiar people who come here, and it has become a daily routine. The staff are energetic and cheerful, so I feel friendly.

reviews.text: Went to see the sunset at the observatory deck, but I got totally surprised by this glass architecture. I arrived after 6pm so this building was closed, otherwise I would love to go inside and explore the design (for me walking around the building was quite exciting already). Recommend family with young kids to visit this place too, I can imagine kids having fun running along it.

It's an interesting building, with the use of stone for the roof, but I wonder if more and more buildings like this should be built with tax dollars.
Maintenance costs will also be high. I don't think it's been that long since they opened, but the glass was cracked and looked like a spider web. I don't think it can be easily replaced.

I visited with some friends who were visiting from Tokyo, and it was cherry blossom season, and there was a zoni shop that sold sweet bean paste. I had a lot of fun as there was a uniquely shaped Yashimaru. The most exciting moments were the moment when the tile went through the hoop, and the moment when the tile caught on my finger and slammed straight down. Or a wild cat? It might be good for cat lovers because there are a lot of cats here.

An exchange base facility located on Mt. Yashima.
The building is shaped like a flowing river, and its roof is made of 30,000 locally produced Aji stones.
There is also a cafe and art exhibits, so you can spend some time relaxing with a panoramic view of Takamatsu city.
Kotoden Yashima, 10 minutes by bus from JR Yashima Station.

There is a bus that runs from Kototenyashima Station to the top of the mountain, so it was easy to climb. Although the weather was a little cloudy, the structure looked great, and there was a cafe inside, so you could take a break during the hot weather. It is a scenic spot where you can overlook Takamatsu city and the surrounding islands at a glance.

The viewpoints are located inside Yashima Temple after some 5-10 minutes walk. Great place to come on a sunny day. Be sure to check out the exhibition and local cafe. If you are taking public transport, you can take the shuttle bus from JR Yashima Station / Kotoden Yashima Station / Shikoku Village. Do check the timing on internet and it is not a frequent service. From the temple, there is a pilgrimage trail descending southbound to the bottom of the mountain. You can opt for this trail instead of waiting for the shuttle bus. It is some easy walks and can connect to some of the nearest Kotoden train stations.
Good views of Takamatsu city and the seto nankai sea. The place has also a temple with some history located at the top. It is free to go anywhere around except an aquarium.
A viewpoint with beautiful ocean scenery.
Do yourself a favour and come here to catch a sunset if you are in the Takamatsu area. Wonderful views. (I'd recommend bringing your own snacks, the nearby cafè was closed when I was there)

There is also a castle boat that runs every 30 minutes between 9:00 and 17:00, and you can board for 500 yen.

reviews.author_name: トレーズクシュリナーダ
reviews.text:
Fish are swimming in the well-maintained moat.
You can also feed them.

It is beautiful compared to other castle moats.
It is rare to see saltwater fish swimming in the moat anywhere else.

Sea bream and fugu are swimming in the moat. It's a surprise.
They sell bait, so you can feed them, but since it was cold, they didn't really bite.
Please be careful.
The moat is full of dogfish....

data.name: Shoko Shoreikan (Commerce and Industry Promotion Hall)

reviews.text: The gallery adjacent to the café hosts an extensive display in both Japanese and English detailing the history of Kagawa's famous Sanuki Udon. Worth a look. Well done!
Very unexpectedly beautiful view at the upper floor balcony--a Must Go site!
Part of Ritsurin Garden
👏wow

data.formatted_address: 340-1 Sogishonishi, Ayagawa, Ayauta District, Kagawa 761-2202, Japan
data.name: Takamatsu Gold Country Club

reviews.text: This is a difficult course advanced players will really enjoy but might stress less able players as it did me! But, I scored a hole-in-one here and so I know I will be back for more! Staff are really nice, very conscientious and service is great. This is about a 50 mins drive from central Takamatsu or 15 mins from the airport if your flying in/out to/from your game. There are many courses around here to choose from including nearby Ayutaki which I also recommend. Practice and take the Takamatsu Gold challenge!
Very good golf club

reviews.author_name: ヘアーサロンくわもと
reviews.text:
From Hiroshima to Kotohira♨Golf.
First visit. If you can hit left and right, there is no narrow OB.
More strategic ◎ Green ◎
18H, 3rd shot over the pond, your mental ability will be tested. Satisfied with par! !

The course and greens are well maintained, and the operation itself seems to have a tradition.
I highly recommend it

It was an extremely difficult course.
I can't say for sure, but I think it's the most difficult in Kagawa. I think it will be fun for advanced golfers, but it is quite a difficult course for amateurs due to the undulations and narrow fairways.
The course was well maintained and clean. Also, the lunch was quite delicious.
Furthermore, it was nice that there was not only a green near the clubhouse, but also a place where you could practice your approach.
However, I was disappointed that the toilets at the teahouses along the course did not have washlet toilets.

This is an interesting pond that reproduces waves.
I feel like it has a faint scent of the ocean.

This is a rare facility unique to Takamatsu, which has been a key point for maritime transportation since ancient times. I think it's a very interesting experiment. I think the area around Takamatsu Station is well maintained and blends perfectly with the surrounding buildings, creating a truly stunning landscape.

This is a rare facility unique to Takamatsu, which has been a key point for maritime transportation since ancient times. I think it's a very interesting experiment. I think the area around Takamatsu Station is well maintained and blends perfectly with the surrounding buildings, creating a A truly stunning landscape.

This is a pond that connects directly to the sea.
Waves occur at a certain timing.
It's a pond, but it's hard to call it a pond lol

A pond with the scent of salt water.
There is a device (JR has apparently come up with a utility model) that takes in seawater and generates artificial waves. Of course, the fish will be swimming before you know it. It is dangerous to get too close to the shore as it can be slippery.

This facility is unique to Takamatsu Station, which faces the Seto Inland Sea. The ocean is just a stone's throw away, and we are directly drawing in seawater that has sunk under the road. The water level changes with the ebb and flow of the tide, and small fish sometimes appear.
A lovely  and not so popular spot. The best part is it's full of rining rocks,  naming *讃岐岩質カンラン玄武岩* in Japanese. While the trail to there was quite broken, I had a great time.

The footing is quite dangerous, but powerful rocks 🪨 suddenly appear and have an impact.
Be careful not to fall even on a sunny day. I don't think it would be possible for an amateur to climb on a day when the weather is bad.

The fence in front of the lighthouse is blocked off, pretending that there is a road in the direction of Tank Rock and the lighthouse, and there is so much grass that it seems impossible to pass.

The scenery may not be worth the steepness of the road.
You'll be climbing over some rocky areas, so you'll need to be prepared for the climb.
If you don't do it well, you'll fall and die, so it's not a place you can go to lightly.
I'm not sure if it's a tank, and I can't clearly see the columnar joints.

It was grassy, ​​the footing was bad, and it was full of dead leaves, so I couldn't find the path, so I gave up midway. It is not recommended for amateurs as there are many unstable stones and there is a high risk of injury.

If you have time, you can come up and have a look. The scenery is nice.
But in the end, the road conditions were not good and it was not suitable for the elderly.
It takes about 40 minutes to climb

24/4/27 ~ 5/5 My 2024GW 8 nights and 9 days Shikoku flow trip (❁´ω`❁)

The long-awaited Cape Takei, the northernmost tip of Shikoku💯
Mainland Japan 5/16 Conquest 😍😍😍
Successfully achieved the goal of this trip, conquering the four poles of Shikoku!

I went down a steep downhill slope and found myself in Shikoku Karst a few days ago.
I was really happy to meet the young people from Buist again🤗
Let's line them up neatly, take pictures, and meet again somewhere~✌

The northernmost sticker at Takei Kannonji Temple...sold out🥺
This is possible! I was given a plastic reflector that looked like a brake light 😂 I bought it for 1000 yen 😂
(When my followers went to buy it the next day, it seemed like it was sold out as well lol)
As I was running towards Seto Ohashi Bridge, I saw a Buist with all its luggage loaded onto an adventure bike, its hair flying in the air.
It's a woman...that's different😳
We ran together for a little while and then said goodbye at the fork!
Memories of a trip with nice young people

There is a parking lot for about 4 to 5 cars, but you'll be heading down a steep slope from the coastal road without much guidance, so it's easy to miss it.

The slope is such that even a car would hesitate for a moment, so if someone who is not used to going down the hill on a motorcycle might be too scared to go up, it is better to think carefully before going down.

There is certainly a stone monument marking the northernmost point of Shikoku, but is this really the northernmost point? Am I the only one who thinks so?
On the map, I feel like the shrine a little further west is the northernmost point.

And the parking lot seems to be the parking lot of a temple called Takei Kannonji (which is quite suspicious). There were also well-equipped public toilets.

There wasn't a note that said it was only for visitors, so it doesn't seem to be a problem if you stop by for a while.

I like edge-of-the-way places and have been to many places, but I felt like I couldn't understand something about this place.

However, as it is a Kannonji temple, it was well maintained and the sandy beach was beautiful, like a private beach.

Although it is not very famous as a tourist destination, it is a highly recommended spot if you have the time. You can see Shodoshima right in front of your eyes, and the boats passing by are also very atmospheric. You can also enter Kannon (200 yen) and the view from the bridge overhanging the cape is amazing. We could see large stone sea bream and flounder (maybe flatfish) swimming below us.

Northernmost point of mainland Shikoku, latitude 34°23'N, longitude 134°8'E
A splendid stone monument befitting the stone town of "Aji" has been erected, and it has become a scenic spot for commemorative photos and views of the mainland.
Compared to Cape Ashizuri, the southernmost tip of Shikoku, the northernmost town, Aji, is probably a lesser-known place.
The road that goes to the tip of the peninsula in the northern part of Kagawa Prefecture is also a road that is not normally traveled.
That's why I feel it's worth visiting.
However, to get here, you have to go down a steep slope. Please be careful where you step.

You can descend from the west side using the signboard as a guide, but please be careful as the slope is steep.
There is a signboard for the northernmost point of Shikoku on the breakwater, and Takei Kannonji Temple is on the left.
After paying the admission fee of ¥300, you will find it in a small shrine after a short walk.
It's a short distance from the entrance, so it ends quickly, but the islands in the Seto Inland Sea were beautiful.

reviews.author_name: John Doe (A Big Hole in Spacetime)
reviews.text: Comprehensive and interesting timeline of Japanese history, along with many cool artifacts. Also some nice art available for viewing. A pretty cheap admission, and a decent walk from the nearest station.
A few exhibitions including history of Kagawa area. I don't think it is a must-visit place but good to stop by if you have some time, as it is right next to Tamamo Park (remains of Takamatsu castle)
Nice little museum with a decent collection of artifacts. However, no translation available ; everything is in Japanese. No pictures allowed except for small sample of modern reconstructions.
The museum is nice. The attached café is absolutely divine. I highly recommend the café for its waffles and ice cream set.
Great experience with authentic Japanese custom !
Beautiful temple with extraordinary views out over the Inland Sea/Seto Naikai and Takamatsu City and port, especially from the overlook on the north and west sides.
An old and beautiful temple with a splendid view.

Huge temple , at the top of Mt. Yashima.
you can find many cute Racoon dogs(Tanuki)
Beautiful temple in a fantastic setting. If you enjoy visiting temples, this one won't disappoint you!

I really loved the shrine and the observation deck. I'd strongly suggest taking the bus (there seems to be no hiking trail anyway). The last bus left at 5:30pm when I was there (couple of days ago). The shrine is very quiet, pretty and has little shops around the observation deck during the day with food, souvenirs and ice cream. You can also buy the lucky charms quite cheap at the shrine!

It was really a relaxing experience. The way up with the cable car was fun and fast. But to walk up to the cable car station you should consider about 20min from the closest station. The temple itself was beautiful and there were not many people. The view over Takamatsu was also one of my favorites. Totally recommend it

We really enjoyed riding to the top and getting to explore the top. I especially enjoyed how few people were around! Being from Tokyo, it is nice to enjoy these views, the cherry trees, and temples without the crowds. Make sure to walk out the see the view of the city. I wish we could’ve been there for sunset.

It's a relatively large temple area which was really quiet and beautiful. I visited on a Sunday afternoon and the place was reasonably empty. There's a cable car you can take up to visit this area, otherwise you can drive here (which I did), where there's a parking area below for around 500yen.

Very beautiful and large temple complex, very well kept by friendly and dedicated staff. Temple #85 of the pilgrimage route. Lots of beautiful buildings and statues, a soft smell of incense hanging in the air. A tranquil and spiritual place. Also an excellent view of Takamatsu.

Pretty nice temple. A lot of the temples in the Shikoku 88 temple pilgrimage are hard to access by transit. This one wasn’t so bad. We took a bus there from Takamatsu and, on the way, we stopped for udon at Udon Honjin Yamadaya (which I highly recommend). Then we caught the cable car up to the shrine. If you are a foreigner, be sure to bring your passport with you as the cost of the ticket is half price with it. Also, if you are a goshuin fan, they make a special goshuin book for the 88 temple pilgrimage that is very beautiful. It has a line drawing of each temple on the page opposite your goshuin stamp. We bought ours at a souvenir shop in Takamatsu before we went.

data.name: Nagasaki no Hana (The Nose of Nagasaki)

reviews.text:
Amazing scenic spot. Beautiful views in all directions.

Not the easiest location to access without a car,

When I went, the path that Google Maps suggested was just walking along the side of the road, which was fine but not ideal. So I'd probably suggest going by car or something similar.

Still, amazing views and worth the trip
Beautiful scenery of the sea and mountains. Peaceful view and rhythmic waves.
A beautiful scenic spot! It’s a short walk down from the parking lot and it overlooks the sea. We saw an amazing sunset from the point. You can climb down to the water as well.
Beautiful place to visit in summer.
Very nice place, almost no people, fresh air. But there is much garbage on the beach.
Good

🏣2-1 Tamamocho, Takamatsu City, Kagawa Prefecture
🅿️🚗…Yes (free)
🚃…1 minute walk from Takamatsu Chikko Station
🚏🚌…Takamatsu Station
*
Opening hours
7:00 to 18:00 (8:00 to 17:00 depending on the season)
Admission fee
200 yen to 100 days
*
Takamatsu Castle Ruins
Also known as…Tamamo Park
first lord of the castle
1587 Chikamasa clan
A rare example of a castle rebuilt on the site of an Edo period castle (as a villa for the Matsudaira family), rebuilt by the 12th head of the family, Mr. Yorihisa Matsudaira.
*
year 2012
Hiunkaku…Former Matsudaira family villa
Designated as a national important cultural property. j
*
Total area: 1,887㎡
It is said that during the Matsudaira clan era, it was a vast building approximately twice the current area.
It was demolished during the Meiji period due to deterioration.
The current Hiunkaku was completed in 1917.
It is said that Emperor Showa and Empress Empress stayed in the 142-tatami large shoin room, Maki-no-ma, Matsu-no-ma, Sotetsu-no-ma, and Nami-no-ma.
After World War II, it was requisitioned by the occupation forces for a while, but it was taken over by Takamatsu City and is now used for rental venues, tea parties, conference rooms, flower exhibitions, etc.
*
Hiunkaku's garden was created in 1903 as Naien Garden by Tokyo gardener Ogo Kanzo.
It became a nationally designated scenic spot in 2013.
*
I'm a little disappointed that it doesn't seem to be open to the public.
Whether you look at the building materials or the structure, it's a structure that can't be seen today...Will it be difficult to maintain and manage?
It was a very stately and wonderful building, a garden, and a structure that I would like everyone to see.

A villa for the Matsudaira clan built in the Taisho era. National important cultural property.
Recently, it has been used as an event venue.
The buildings and gardens are beautiful and feature a lot of cycads.
There is a shoe rack at the entrance where you can put your shoes. I don't have the key, so I have to be careful about theft.
There is an administrative office in the building. The inside of the building is quite old.
It is said to have been used as the domain's government office and the residence of the domain lord.

During the Edo period, there was a palace called Hiunkaku in this area of ​​Takamatsu Castle, where government affairs were held and where the feudal lord lived, but it was demolished after the Meiji Restoration due to deterioration. After that, Count Saiju, the 12th head of the Takamatsu Matsudaira family, started rebuilding in 1917, and the current Hiunkaku was completed in 1917, taking over three years. (reduced by about half). Although it was built as a villa for the Matsudaira family, it also served as a guesthouse for guests visiting Kagawa. Currently, the hall is rented out, and various events such as tea parties, concerts, and photo sessions are held here.

Beautiful lighthouse. About a 2km walk from the port.

Bring a can of Pringles if you understood the reference hahaha.

a lighthouse along with a small camping area next to it.
you cant enter the lighthouse, but rather the information / history center next to it.

this is around a 30 mins walk from ogijima port. please remember to reserve time or else you will miss your ship.

the view here is fine, not particularly amazing (might be because i arrived there at noon, not sunrise/sunset).

the beach next to it can be accessed, but theres a lot of insects. not recommend going down as camping area is provided, and you cant swim there.

a great place to visit if youre not in a hurry, or else petting cats is a better option.

Without doubt, one of my favourite places. Camped twice in the lighthouse grounds and on the beach. Has an uninhabited vibe about it out of season. I camped in November, so I was mostly camping alone. There were a couple of other tents on a couple of nights though. The lighthouse is impressive and the museum, when open, is informative. Best if you like solitude and watching ships go by.
This lighthouse and the auxiliary facilities seemed to have been abandoned as of late 2019.  It’s a 40 minute walk from the pier but not a long to see along the way.

Beautiful lighthouse and on one of my favorite places to visit in the Seto Inland Sea. I really mean it. It’s great and I hope more people could get more information about it and the whole island of Ogijima!

環境舒服!! The environment is very comfortable, The 北浜アリー (きたはまアリー) is a house which made from Cargo. In the "Alley",  many shops are opened by the creative owner. There included some feature cafe, some hand-made souvenir  shop. Very relax place with nice view!!!!!!
Boring place and only a few store without variety. Can better renovate or revatailize something else... Not worth to visit there unless you want to chill a while by walking and a coffee...
Much worse than expected. Just only few stores exist. Also, most of them close early even in the evening on Friday. Not so bad but no reason to visit again.
Nice culture and stores there

Cool little revitalised area, seems like a local hipster area but less pretentious than its Western counterparts.  The Cafe itself is pretty cool and typically stocked with books and niknacks. The coffee is decent,  not like the amazing places in bigger cities but alright. For those who like sweet drinks,  cakes and other sweets it's good.  Also the stew and salad we had were really good. The downside is we had to wait about 30 mins each time even on a Monday afternoon.

Not stunning in Summer🥹
But it is okay with you want to take some pictures there!
Such a quiet and lovely place to visit during Cherry blossom season.

Place was a little bit small to make a detour when you're in town, had to walk 15 mins through local neighborhood from the station if you're using the tram. Not much crowd, beautiful sight nonetheless.
A nice place to take a walk, even outside sakura blossoming season. In the middle of the walk, you can stop to say hello to the Koi fish which reside there.
Nice place
The cherry blossoms in this season are beautiful indeed.
Sometimes, I feel that Takamatsu lacks nice, fun and relaxing parks, just to spend time outside and relax. Here is a great one, good both for adults and kids.
Even in the rain you can tell its an amazing park with a great playground, indoor pool  and gym
Spacey with good playgrounds and beautiful surroundings. Recommended for picnics!
Clean area good for visitors.
A good place to walk to when you are in Takamatsu. If got some time, wait yo watch moving reflection of the red team that passes by the castle.
Cute castle tower, but you can't enter
Fooled by photos that this is the Castle. It is not but still a nicely built building.

The interior will only be open to the public on May 5th, the anniversary of Tamamo Park's opening. I was able to go up to the third floor. Unusually for a turret, there are no bars on the windows. It's a sight you don't usually see.

Takamatu castle is a good place to visit while you are in the city. There are two main entrances for the castle. One is near by Takamatsu-chikko station, and the main entry at the southeast corner of the castle. Enterance fee was 200Yen. It took about an hour to look around. It is not a big castle such in Osaka or Nagoya. The inner part of the castle it is now a quiet place to take a walk. Castle surrounded by a moat, and it uses water from the sea. You could see some fish in the moat and looks like they are sea fish. Some structures of the castle remain, but the main part of the castle is missing. However, while you walk around, you could see what is looked like before.

It is a place worth visiting in Takamas. There are two entrances. One is right next to Takamatsu-chikko Station, and the main entrance is located in the southeast. The entrance fee was 200 yen. It is not a castle as big as Osaka or Naoya. The inside of the castle is relatively quiet and there is a moat throughout and inside the castle. Marine fish live inside the moat, probably using the seawater. It's a bit disappointing that only part of the castle building remains.

This is a small temple that is convenient to visit when you are heading for the Shikoku Village nearby.

While there is nothing particularly special about it, it is nice to climb up the (many) stairs as the view from the top gives you an idea of what that area of Takamatsu looks like.
The shrine was huge but cozy. It is worth to have a walk here.
Not particularly impressive temple, but view from the top is great!
眺望がよい場所❤︎
very　nice😄

Amazing temple. It doesn't look like anything, but it houses a room that will surprise you (I don't even want to tell you what's inside). Also, it has one of the newest pagodas in Japan. On top of the hill is where the Matsudaira clan (former rulers of Takamatsu) are buried.

This is a magnificent temple that is the second of the 25 sacred sites of Enko Daishi of the Jodo sect. There is also the Matsudaira family grave. The five-storied pagoda was also amazing.
However, I am disappointed that I collect the goshuin stamps with the three-leaf Aoi stamp (the last photo) in one goshuin book (here they are stamped with the Shichifukujin goshuin stamp). An elderly woman mistakenly wrote the stamp of Enko Daishi's 25 Sacred Sites in her stamp book.
When I asked him why, he didn't tell me which goshuin, so he said he wrote one of the 25 sacred sites, which he often writes about.
It's probably wrong that I didn't mention it, but if there are two types of goshuin, what kind of goshuin should the elderly person write here? I thought I should have asked, and I should have listed the types of goshuin stamps as an example.
In the end, someone else came and talked with them, and they ended up forcibly stamping the seal of the 25 Sacred Sites with the Mitsuba Aoi seal, and they apologized.
The money was taken without incident.
In 90% of other shrines and temples, if you make a mistake, they won't charge you for the stamp.
I got a Reana Goshuin stamp, but a little lump remained.
Most temples display the types of stamps at the reception desk, so I think this temple should follow suit.
Visit 2024.4.23

It's a very beautiful and quiet temple. The stairs are steep and a little scary, but once you climb up you'll be rewarded with a peaceful view of Takamatsu. It's a spectacular view.
There are a variety of graves on the mountain, from very old to very new ones, and the plots are not as well-maintained as modern cemeteries, so it was amazing to feel the history of the people there.

This was my first visit even though I'm in Takamatsu City. Honenji Garan has a magnificent precinct, including the main hall, which is centered around a five-tiered tower. This time, the statue of Honen Shonin's Nirvana will be away for about two years for a traveling exhibition in Hakata, Kyoto, Tokyo, so I hurriedly visited it at the end of March. I was overwhelmed by the numerous statues of the human body, including the Nirvana statue. Next time I would like to visit Okunoin etc.🎵

A temple associated with Honen Shonin, who founded the Jodo sect.
It is a splendid temple where good old buildings and new buildings naturally coexist without any discomfort.
You can see Syachihoko here

2017.6.30

Get it for free
Traditional crafts from Kagawa Prefecture were on display.
exterior
Admission is free. It is fully equipped with air conditioning and heating, so you can feel free to stop by, and there are not many people, so you can enjoy the exhibits without hesitation.
A model of Takamatsu Castle and items related to it are on display.

A host of different activities can be done at this luxurious park offering a variety of slides, bits of playgrounds and an expansive oval for doing any such ball related activities, kiting, or riding one's strider to even being a perfect picnic place.

Just be careful the antlion pit can be dangerous with too many people at once.

Good place for a little walk and hiking or camping
Beautiful birds eye view as well

I went there in spring, there were spots to sit and just enjoy the view. We found an artificial cave too. There is also an athletic camping site for groups. However, it is quite far away from public transport. It is better to have a car otherwise you will have to hitchhike or hike
Wintertime not best to go walk or you need to be active all the time
Huge park with lots of play places for the kids and open spaces for the adults and teens.

The sunlight entered the tree through the gaps at the base of its sturdy trunk, giving it a strong and gentle feel. The surrounding ground was also well-maintained, and I got the impression that it was like a painting, not just of the pine itself, but of the surrounding area as well.
Also, as a traveler, I was able to take some satisfying photos as the course was set up for a wooden boat to pass through, and it became a great memory.
Goyomatsu looks different from a Japanese boat.

data.formatted_address: 1132-1 大町 牟礼町 Takamatsu, Kagawa 761-0122, Japan
data.name: George Nakashima Memorial Museum

reviews.text: The official studio and gallery in Japan for George Nakashima of New Hope, PA USA. The video by his nephew which is an award-winning documentary gives you a great understanding of George Nakashima. If you are shipping to the United States you cannot purchase in Japan due to licensing. You must purchase in the United States for shipping in the United States. GH

For those who are into mid century furniture this is a great inspiration and a font of knowledge of the work of Nakashima. Those with $$$ may wish to purchase an item or two Or just dream
like me.
You will get to know George Nakashima in a very personal way. You can sit on some of the replica, very well done.
Worth the detour if you love nikkei culture, furniture and or woodworking 💯
Beautiful exhibit of Nakashima’a designs
Cozy, peaceful, and beautiful place

The scale of the museum is small.

If you have a disability certificate, you can view it for free whether you have an intellectual disability, a mental disability, or a physical disability.

It's a one-story building, with two doors, and a fair amount of depth, but with that size, I don't think we could hold more than four exhibitions even if we squeezed it all together.
There were two exhibitions going on when I went.
One is a photo exhibition.
The other is an exhibition of paintings by an artist who started out as a school teacher.

There is a coffee shop attached, but it doesn't seem to be open on weekdays because there aren't many customers. I don't know if they are open on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays.
I was disappointed in this point, as I was hoping to enjoy some delicious coffee and kill some time.

What I was most excited about this time was not the art exhibition;
This is a divine dragonfly (Gokuraku dragonfly) that was abundant outdoors in the wild.
It probably has another official name, but it is a dragonfly with black wings and a metallic green body.

In the 1970s, before construction of the Nagao Bypass began, it was commonplace to see it around Rokujo Town. Nowadays, you can only see a few red dragonflies around Rokujo Town, and you almost never see dragonflies in rice fields.

I was fascinated by the dragonflies, filled with nostalgia and rarity.

I stopped by for a walk on a Sunday when I had no plans. I was a little worried because there was no one there even though it was Sunday, but the guy at the reception greeted me with great energy and made me happy. The exhibition consists of two small rooms. I'm an amateur at drawing, but I enjoyed the many different types of drawings. I liked the paintings by the artist from Shione. It's only 300 yen to enter, so I'd like to go again. I was able to go in and enjoy something out of the ordinary, look outside at nature, and feel refreshed. The "information corner" outside was a very relaxing space, and I came back thinking that it would be nice if it was a cafe or something. I guess it's impossible, but could you at least put a cup vending machine (^^)

Yoshifumi Oshima's works were on display. Insects are arranged in a crowded space, and the spider hanging smoothly from the ceiling is also shocking. It is full of swarms of ants, cicadas, dragonflies, spiders, beetles, and beetles.
Fern Coffee Shop's lunch, coffee, and analog amplifier BGM are the best in the forest! ️

I was once again happy to see such an active person in my hometown. I am grateful that I was able to experience so many works, including works that express post-war feelings and works that viewers can enjoy while integrating with each other. It's a place I'd like to visit again in different seasons.

The atelier and residence of world-renowned sculptor Masayuki Nagare will be opened to the public this fall as Nagare Studio.
The large collection of works and the impressive fortress-like studio that makes you wonder if it is privately owned.
The outdoor exhibition effectively creates a different space between the sea and the sky of the Seto Inland Sea, making use of the elevated location, making it open and familiar.
In addition, the indoor exhibition is displayed in each space on the first and second floors, along with the folk implements he has collected, creating a good contrast with his works.
A number of works by Masayuki Nagare are lined up against the backdrop of a location overlooking the sky and sea of ​​Takamatsu. It was a really nice place for someone like me who loves stones.

A garden that makes you feel like you have the Seto Inland Sea all to yourself.
Although there are many works of art, it is clean and the trees are well-maintained. Best of all, we spent an hour in a small group listening to explanations from volunteers. You can feel relaxed and elegant.

It was a rotating system where the guide was always there to listen to explanations. The location is great and the artwork is amazing, but I wanted to enjoy it in peace and quiet. I would like to go again if I can view it freely.
Unfortunately, the entrance fee is a little high. You can also enjoy Mr. Kawashima's works. The location was perfect, matching the scenery of the Seto Inland Sea.

reviews.author_name: すぎもとりか（まんつう）
reviews.text: You can see many of Takeshi Kawashima's works in the beautiful environment of Setouchi.
It was my first time to visit the museum, and although it was only half an hour with a kind and thorough guide, I left a good impression.

If you are a group, you can make a reservation in advance and get admission inside for a fee.
Painter Takeshi Kawashima's atelier and exhibition room
You can listen to stories from the creators, view exhibitions of their works, and see collections of ethnographic materials.
The problem is that public transportation is very poor.

This is a visit from outside the prefecture.
I've been sightseeing in Kagawa Prefecture, but I didn't know that there was a specialty called Aji stone. There are exhibits where you can learn about a wide range of things related to stones, not just this specialty stone. I didn't know much about ores, but the history related to stones and many of the exhibits were carefully explained using puppets of stone crushers.

There are other museums about stones, but this one has a highly designed building and a large grassy park, and is located on a slightly higher ground so you can enjoy the view.
The entrance fee is also very cheap at 200 yen (adult).

It's also interesting that the shop sells stone goods.
Many of them are reasonably priced.

There were also special exhibitions that were not related to stones.
This time it's an exhibition called Shintaro Miyawaki's PHOTO & BOOK, and not only are you allowed to take photos, but you can also pick up the books on display (✖ in the photo).
There was an interesting book that I picked up and read, so it took me a while.

Although there is still no end in sight to the coronavirus pandemic, I visited (^O^)👍️
The weather was unfortunate with occasional light rain, but I felt lucky that it wasn't raining during the walk! ️The parking lot is large and there is a WC, so it is a fully equipped facility in various aspects.
My impressions of this place are that it is a beautiful facility that takes advantage of the area's rich nature.
It's a place where you can find historical information about various stones, their unique formation conditions from ancient times, and information that transcends the flow of time in a compact and easy-to-understand manner, and where you can explore interestingly using dioramas and TV monitors! ️ (^O^)v Good 👍️
In addition, the admission fee for adults was also cheap at 200 yen❗It's easy to use! ️
I was able to purchase some of our works that put a smile on my face and make me feel at ease, such as objects made from stone, vases, and pen holders! ️(^O^)👌
This time I bought a paperweight❗It looks a bit manic, but the center above the lotus position is a Sanskrit character (representing Fudo Myoo)!! ️Both sides represent (Seitaka Douji) and (Kongara Douji)❗
I apologize for the information being irrelevant to those who are not interested m(_ _)m Please forgive me.
There is also play equipment outside that even small children can enjoy, so I think it is a facility that everyone from adults to children can enjoy! ️(^O^)👍️Good
I would like to purchase some interesting works by stone masters on my next visit! ️(^O^)👌Ok

Turn right just before Yakuri-dera Temple.
There is a plaza with playground equipment, a stone wall, and a stone folk museum!
There was a giraffe on display created by the sculptor Okayama, so I went to see it.
The plaza has a nice view and is perfect for playing with children!
The stone benches and objects are also cute.
There is a fee to enter some of the Stone Folklore Museums, but it might be worth checking out at least once. The history of stonemasonry is quite interesting.

It was my first time visiting and I really enjoyed it.
The children were especially fascinated by stone hunting, looking for beautiful stones.
I want to go there again.
I got a good understanding of the history and types of stone, how to quarry Aji stone, and the tools.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒761-8021 香川県高松市鬼無町
data.name: Katsuga Castle Ruins

reviews.text: A lovely place for a family outing, the path up is just tiring enough to keep the kids calm, and the huge area on top can let them go wild. Plenty of learning to be done and an amazing bakery at the base of the mountain.

Katsuga Castle.
Sakon General Kansaimura, a descendant of the Sanuki Fujiwara clan, built a castle on Mt. Katsuga as a shugo and established a residence in Saryo due to his success in the Jokyu War.
From then on, the Kozai clan ruled, but the 18th generation, Yoshikiyo, became a subordinate of Motochika and ended with Hideyoshi's invasion of Shikoku.
There is a castle entrance information board on the road north of Kagawa Seiryo Junior and Senior High School, and if you follow the paved farm road, you will find the entrance and parking for several cars.
You can take the mountain trail to the main fort without getting lost.
There is a pamphlet with a territory map at the shrine stone pillar in the center of the main building.
The flat main building is surrounded by earthworks and is full of attractions such as multiple tiger mouths, the surrounding square curves, and the stone masonry on the northeast side.
It took about 20 minutes from the entrance to the main building.
I'm a bit worried, but if you continue ahead, there is a parking lot at the entrance to the trailhead. You can also stop on nearby public roads. Always available 2024.6

The remains of the castle ruins are well preserved and worth seeing. The earthworks and moat surrounding the main fort were interesting. I wasn't able to explore much after seeing the sign warning of vipers, but it was a lot of fun. It is also registered as a peak on the mountain climbing app, and the mountain trail is also in good condition. I drove up from the Saryo Castle side to near the trailhead and then walked.

This castle has a parking lot and a mountain trail.
The castle ruins are also well maintained by the preservation society.
You can clearly see the earthworks that are the highlight!
It is a castle with considerable remains such as stone masonry and vertical earthworks! ️

Excellent view tea house, friendly staff, even reminded us to take a look around inside the tea house when we planned to leave, it was worth the visit as the back of the tea house also have a fantastic view……….they have different seating areas including chairs for people who doesn’t like to sit in the traditional Japanese style mat……a very good rest stop when you are inside the ritsurin garden…….

A small pavilion in Ritsurin Park
Matcha and Japanese sweets (manju) for 500 yen
If you pay first and sit inside, they will bring it to you and clean it up for you.
Great place to escape the heat or sun
The manager is very friendly

Matcha affogato with soy sauce bean ice cream 850 yen
You can enjoy an elegant matcha tea ceremony.

This pavilion is a replica of the shogun's tea room style from the Edo period. Instead of just eating Sanuki udon, you can make a lunch reservation at your accommodation (a day in advance) and receive a seasonal meal (3,000 yen, which is expensive) personally served by a kimono-clad manager (who waits at the door 5 minutes in advance with his hands folded) to enjoy your Japanese experience. Enjoy traditional hospitality from the samurai era. Tea and drinks (worth 500-700 yen) are of course free, and of course you will also receive a free admission ticket to Kikugetsudai, which is managed (not received) by this tea room. Experience the etiquette and formality of putting a receipt in an envelope. I only upload photos that I have taken along the way that don't exist before, and I can't upload videos related to drinks and refreshments because I don't have the technology.

A place where rain suddenly poured down and I entered without realizing it.
It's nice because it has charm.
It wasn't until I left that I realized that if you show Fukiagetei the receipt of what you ate here, the drinks are free.. (maybe there's a discount)
It is said that it is only possible on the same day.
Since it's at the entrance, it might be a good idea to stop by and go inside to have a cup of tea.

data.name: Site of Kurogane-mon Gate (Takamatsu Castle Ruins)

reviews.text: I imagine that there must have been a magnificent gate.

reviews.author_name: 小林素明[大阪]パーソナルトレーナー
reviews.text:
Visited on 2022/07/24
Although it no longer exists, there used to be an iron gate here to enter the Ninomaru from the Sannomaru.

Visited on June 27, 2021.
It is said that there used to be an iron gate here. There is an instruction manual for more details.
It's on the northwest side of the park.
Tranquil garden and enchanting castle ruins. Beautiful to walk amongst and learn about the history of this place. 🚻 vending machine and water fountain.

This gate is located at the Sannomaru entrance of Takamatsu Castle in Takamatsu City, Kagawa Prefecture. The gate from the Edo period was apparently destroyed in the Takamatsu air raid, and was restored in 2022.
The pillars and beams are brand new and impressive, and there is a dark blue curtain with a cherry blossom crest on it, and lanterns with a trefoil hollyhock pattern on both sides, giving it a very nice atmosphere.
The inside was also open to the public, so I took a tour.

Visit period: June 2024
It is a splendid gate with Aoi no Gomon.

This is a beautifully restored gate.
The tree is thick!
There are three types of curtains attached to the gate.
It seems that it will be changed depending on the event.

reviews.author_name: 小林素明[大阪]パーソナルトレーナー
reviews.text:
Visited on 2022/09/24

This is a beautifully restored Sakura Gomon gate. Once inside, you will see a stone drop to prevent enemy invasion, as well as roof tiles and wood used in the Sakura Gomon gate. The children were happy to be able to touch the wood.

reviews.text:
There's just a smooth rail
It is an unpopular space with many unmanned counters.
buried door

A place with scenic beauty and a refreshing atmosphere. You can't get enough of the birds chirping. Watching sunset from here is a feast for your eyes! You're bound to feel better after visiting the place!
Wonderful and traquill place to visit. During spring season where this pond surrounded with cherry blossom tree and Iwate mouth in background shows the magnificent view.
Ths best lake in Morioka. Really enjoy walking and playing here.
It's very beautiful place. I love there.

Lovely walk around the pond. Can rent a swan boat to paddle around too. Plenty of pokestops, ducks, swans in the winter, koi, even turtles! Small rose garden, and a grassy area for picnics. At least two public toilets,  and a nearby cafe if you want to sit inside. Very popular during sakura season when there are yatai food stalls.
First time in my life touching so many types of animals in this zoo. It’s fun for all ages. Recommended.

If you love getting close to Animals for feeding opportunity this is the zoo for you. The animals and exhibits are also not too far away so the walking is very manageable. I would recommend if you have kids. The lemurs were all over me on my shoulders and eating carrots. I love this place. Also cheap entry.

A mid-size private zoo located in east Kagawa, about 1 hour away Takamatsu downtown area. It’s designed for short range observation as well as interaction. You can buy carrot, banana etc. to feed some of animals. You can also join scheduled animal touch or feeding. Good to kids who love animals. The campus is not always flat and you need to walk up and down through some small hills.

There was a wide variety of Animals at the zoo. They have lions, tigers, a wide bird collection, elephants, zebra just to name a few. They also had a petting zoo area for kids with rabbits, baby chicks and hamsters. You can even buy vegetables to feed animals as you move around their habitats.

The downside for me was how the animals were situated. It was a lot of fences and seeing the larger animals were difficult even take pictures were somewhat obstructed. Also there is a lot of loose soil and the day I went it was very windy and the dirt was everywhere.

PS: I would have loved to have seen the hippo in actual water and the elephant around trees etc.

Heartbreaking experience, extremely inhumane zoo. The person who recommended it made it sound like a breeding sanctuary but it’s not, it’s a prison for animals. If you are expecting humane breeding programmes this is not the place for you. We left very shortly after walking in, some in tears. These animals deserve so much better

Tallest building in Takamatsu, free entry to the observation deck on the 29th floor. You can get a good view of the city and the harbour. Went there on Monday at about 11am, it was very quiet. Free of charge, worth visiting.

The tower was located in the waterfront.  The railway terminal was very near.  Next to the building was a signature park in the city.  The shopping mall on the lower floors were restaurants and shops.  Many parking lots were available underground.  The lifts leading to the observation level were free.  Chairs and long desks were placed there for people to take a rest and enjoy the view.  Toilets were clean.  There was a restaurant operating on the higher floor.  The night scene should be specular.  Nothing was selling on this floor.  The atmosphere was quiet and relaxing.
Good viewpoint at Level 29 (free access) to observe the Seto Inland sea and the city. Limited seatings available

reviews.text: This is a great spot for an evening stroll, as the walkway boasts an incredible atmosphere. The lighthouse is a sight to behold, whether it's day or night, and truly adds to the overall wonder of the area.
Best for a calm night walk.Nice view.
Very nice view, especially the sunset. Clean place, but because of the ferry’s you can smell the exhausts.
Very good for a jogging exercise, you can see a lot of people looking for pokemon to catch.😂 I've travel from shizuoka-ken to kagawa-ken just to see this place.

reviews.text: A pleasant stroll by the sea. Looks like you ought to be able to climb up inside, but no luck when I tried. Outside is a bust too. Still, it's very red, isn't it?

Visited on June 27, 2021.
It is nicknamed the couple's pine because the red pine and black pine combine to look like a single pine.
That's amazing.

There are lots of places to see.
Look up, Oak.
It has been designated as a prefectural natural monument.

Visited on June 27, 2021.
An oak tree that is rare in the park. It's called Negami Oak. For more details, please see the explanation board.

A great place to see and shop for bonsai, pots, soil, tools, etc if you're buying domestically. Allow plenty of time to look around because there's a lot!
Parking is plentiful and free. Staff was helpful when I had questions. I would definitely go again.

I came here because Takamatsu is famous for its bonsai.
It has many shelves and is said to have 10,000 bonsai on display at any given time.
It takes about 40 minutes to finish watching everything.
I purchased a red pine tree with roots.
Apparently there are many bonsai gardens in the area, so I'd like to visit all of them next time.

You can get a manhole card.

Below is a brief introduction to the facility.
Opened in April 2020. The western area of ​​Takamatsu City, Kagawa Prefecture is Japan's number one pine bonsai production area, boasting an 80% share of the national market, and there are always over 10,000 bonsai and seedlings on display, making it easy for enthusiasts to purchase. The bonsai on display and for sale include traditional Takamatsu specialty pine bonsai such as Kuromatsu, Goyomatsu, and Nishikimatsu, as well as affordable wildflowers, moss balls, and a wide variety of fertilizers and tools for maintenance. We have it in stock.
I went there to get a manhole card, and there were a lot of bonsai in the back, so I wanted to take a look.

We were given free cherry blossoms and had a chance to try planting them.
The JA staff and teachers were very kind and the children were very happy.
Now I water it every day.

The facility and parking lot were both well-maintained and very clean.
A good place for kids to run and have fun. Not too many facilities here, but the big lawn is good enough for family to spend time.

Sanuki Airport Park has entry and closing times, so please be careful when using it. It's right next to the airport, so kids will love being able to see planes up close. This is a separate facility from Sanuki Kodomo no Kuni, which is located on the south side of Takamatsu Airport, so please be careful not to confuse them when meeting up.
It's relatively crowded on Saturdays and Sundays, but on weekdays it's less crowded and you can relax.
During the summer, children can be seen playing in the pond within the park.
Walking along the promenade in the park is a good way to get some exercise as it is quite a distance.
There are vending machines and restrooms, so I think you can spend a long time there if you bring your own lunch, and if you get bored, you might want to go to the nearby Sanuki Children's Country.

It's nice to watch planes take off and land, but the seasonal flowers are blooming so you can take a leisurely stroll.
You can also take your dog for a walk in the eastern area.
It's also a favorite spot for my kids.

You can see Yashima🎵👍️☀️If the weather is nice, you can also see the ocean.
The lawn is well-maintained, and families with children can play leisurely. Fun for airplane lovers 😊
There's not much shade, so it's tough in the summer🌞.

I don't know if you can call it play equipment, but it's interesting art. There are play equipment
Children will love it too.

reviews.text: Highly recommend, Saru interactions everywhere :) Please make effort to climb/walk to observation viewpoint too, it is one of best views on island

it is a small zoo full of wild monkeys so need to be careful. Do not stare at them otherwise they might attack you. Don't run and don't play with monkeys. However, it is a good experience for everyone. Also, they didn't advertise it but they have the best view points in the whole island.

For those with kids. It’s about a 5-10 mins walk to the kingdom. There’s also a cabin to feed the monkeys safely. The staff are very aware of the monkey’s behaviors and give advice to visitors accordingly to prevent incidents.

For those with better endurance. Walk 20 mins to the top of the mountain for some mind bending views of the area.
Perfect place to meet with our ancestor in funny way. You can feed them too :-)
I recommend to go all the way up the hill to have great way around Shodoshima.
We were leaving Morioka and thought we had time for a short walk, but we didn't realize how large this place is! The park is gorgeous and the view is amazing. We will be back to walk the full trail.

Very good spot to absorb the view of Mt Iwate over the pond. Peaceful and relaxing. Note that the sun would set over the Mt in the evening, so it might be better for photographers to avoid the sunset.
The pond looks great with a large park where kids can play joyfully!
It took me awhile to figure out how the bus route to get there. However, it’s worthy.
Good place for walking end enjoyed nature.

reviews.text: Although it was cloudy on this day ☁️ It was hot and humid 😣 This place was cool and pleasant ☺️ Chihuahua also came for a walk with his mom and dad 🐕 It was heartwarming 🥰

Although it is a small and narrow waterfall, the water is abundant and cool even in midsummer, making it a great place to play in nature.

The basin of the waterfall was probably 160cm deep, and there were children around elementary school age jumping in around it. If you move away from there, you will find a place that is about the depth of an adult's knees to thighs.
There were many children catching small fish and loaches.
The area near the waterfall basin is rocky and the footing is difficult, but everyone makes their way down to the water's edge.
A little further down from the waterfall, there are stairs that lead down to the river.

The parking lot is small, with benches and no restrooms.

Be especially careful of vipers in the evening.
It's a healing space.
It's a nice place.

data.name: Nijino Falls

reviews.text: The road is paved with concrete, but it is narrow and sometimes has large stones falling, so you need to be careful on the way to get there. The water is clear and very clean. If you look closely, you'll see fish, crabs, and small shrimp, so even the adults sit down and look into the water, fascinated. The time goes by quickly, about 2 hours. Of course, swimming is also fun. The water is extremely cold. There are no restrooms or vending machines until you reach the campsite. It is a landscape that I want to remain like this forever.

This is a spectacular waterfall that is rare in Kagawa Prefecture. There's plenty of water, and there's a nice campsite with a parking lot and toilets just a short walk from the national highway. Just a few minutes up the mountain, you'll see a lot of maple trees around you, and if you pass through them, you'll see a waterfall. there is. It's the perfect place to cool down in the summer and see the autumn leaves in the fall.
I love this place.

reviews.text: It is said that Sugawara no Michizane, who served as Sanuki no kami for four years from 886 to 890, used to go boating in this pond and look at the moon over Mt. Now, a swan 🦢 is playing in the water instead of Michizane. Recently, some people have seen storks from Hyogo Prefecture coming to visit via Tokushima.

You can take reflection shots of the sunrise from Mt. Mine and the sunset over Goshikidai.
Migratory birds such as swans also come (^-^)
Please be careful as it is considered bad etiquette to go down to the water or feed wild animals.
There are two pairs of swans. Depending on the season, there may even be baby swans.
